column7: Whitehaven is the leading Australian producer of high-quality, high-CV thermal coal. Our thermal and metallurgical coal products are exported to premium markets in Asia.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Whitehaven Coal Limited ('Whitehaven' or 'the Company') is a for-profit entity, and the principal activity of Whitehaven and its controlled entities (referred to as 'the Group') is the development and operation of coal mines in New South Wales and Queensland.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column13: We continue to regard the recommendations of the Financial Stability Board's Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) and the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB) Coal Operations Standard. Our TCFD disclosures detail how we consider climate-related governance, strategy, risk management, metrics, and targets. A SASB Coal Standard Index, which indicates where each topic has been referenced in our disclosures, is included on the Sustainability page of our website.

column7: This data has been subject to limited assurance by EY for NGER reporting.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column13: In April 2023, Whitehaven announced that the Board had approved a ~$150m investment to commence early mining of the Vickery coal deposit, which will utilise surplus coal processing and washing infrastructure capacity at the Gunnedah CHPP as well as existing road haulage, rail and port capacity. Work commenced in the June 2023 quarter to advance the Early Stage Mining project, including the design of temporary mine infrastructure facilities, preparation and tendering of construction works and mobilisation of a dedicated project and operations team to the site. Feasibility works are ongoing for the full-scale project, with an investment in full-scale development to be considered by the Board at an appropriate time.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column8: Winchester South open-cut metallurgical coal mine
column13: On 31 March 2023, the Winchester South project team submitted the Response to Submissions Report to the Office of the Coordinator-General (OCG), which responded to all submissions received during the public notification of the Revised Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) in December 2022. On 7 July 2023, the EIS was formally accepted by the OCG as the final EIS for the Winchester South project. The OCG is now preparing a report evaluating the EIS. The project continues to progress through the Queensland Government's coordinated approval process. The project team continues to complete a feasibility study with detailed studies underway across all project work streams.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column13: The Narrabri Stage 3 Extension Project is an extension of the existing Narrabri underground mine. It will extend the longwall panels planned for the mining lease south of the current main roads into the contiguous Narrabri South Exploration Licence area and extend the approved life of the mine from 2031 to 2044.

1,457 contractors
Audit and Risk Management Committee, Remuneration Committee, Governance and Nomination Committee, Health, Safety, Environment and Community Committee.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column7: As part of appointing new Directors, the Governance and Nomination Committee undertakes appropriate background checks on potential appointees' character, experience, education, criminal record, and bankruptcy history. Equivalent checks are also undertaken before putting a candidate to shareholders for election as a Director.

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: The Hon. Mark Vaile AO, Chairman Non-Executive Director, Appointed: 3 May 2012

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board is responsible for approving and monitoring the implementation and execution of our ESG strategy and performance. It is supported by the advice from the Board Health, Safety, Environment and Community (HSEC) Committee and the Audit and Risk Management Committee.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: Whitehaven's Managing Director and CEO, supported by the Executive Leadership Team, is responsible for implementing and managing the strategic approach set by the Board, including integration in operational strategies, action plans and reporting. The Managing Director and CEO have operational responsibility for sustainability matters. Other Executive Leadership Team members with particular responsibilities relating to sustainability matters include the Chief Financial Officer, Executive General Manager (EGM) Ã¢ÂÂ Health, Safety and Environment, the EGM Ã¢ÂÂ People & Culture, and the EGM Ã¢ÂÂ Corporate, Government & Community Affairs.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Board, with the assistance of the Audit and Risk Management Committee, is responsible for internal compliance and control frameworks and reviews. It also oversees our codes of ethics, conduct, and legal and regulatory compliance.

Conflicts of interest arise if you participate in an activity or have financial or personal relationships where those interests or loyalties jeopardise or have the potential to jeopardise your objectivity, independence or otherwise be perceived to compromise you in your work at Whitehaven. We must professionally undertake all business activities and be alert when our interests align with our professional interests. If you are still determining, discuss a potential conflict of interest with management or Whitehaven's Company Secretary. You are expected to identify and disclose any conflict of interest immediately.

In addition to internal reporting channels, our independent whistleblower hotline, operated by Navex Global, allows individuals to report potential misconduct anonymously. All reports made are received and treated sensitively and thoughtfully and are dealt with promptly, fairly and objectively.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: The Board is committed to identifying and attracting suitably experienced leaders to ensure it has the right directors. In terms of composition, the Board believes that its current Directors possess an appropriate mix of skills, experience and diversity to enable the Board to discharge its responsibilities and deliver the Company's corporate objectives.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: The Board periodically evaluates the performance of the Board, its Committees and its Directors. The evaluation encompasses a review of the structure and operation of the Board and its Committees, the skills and characteristics required by the Board to maximise its effectiveness, the performance of its Committees and Directors, and the appropriateness of the Board's practices and procedures to meet the present and future needs of the Company.

column13: At the core of our new remuneration framework is the Single Incentive Plan (SIP), which replaced our Short-term Incentive (STI) Plan and Long-term Incentive (LTI) Plan. The SIP better reflects shareholder interests by focusing on critical annual operational imperatives and aligning with shareholders through material equity components and more extended deferral periods.

column7: The Board delegates and oversees the Remuneration committee about remuneration policies. The Remuneration committee make recommendations and reports to the Board.

column13: We strive for excellence in executing our business strategy, delivering on our purpose and operating responsibly and sustainably. We recognise that solid sustainability management and performance is vital in creating value for our customers, workforce, communities, suppliers and shareholders. We embed environmental, social and governance (ESG) matters in our strategic priorities, decision-making, action plans and practices and focus on developing and improving our approach.

column7: Whitehaven's Board is committed to achieving the highest standards of corporate governance, transparency and accountability. Our corporate governance structures and processes underpin our sustainability approach and progress.
We are committed to operating ethically and with integrity. Responsible business conduct and practices are central to how we manage and are embedded in our operations.

We are committed to protecting internationally recognised human rights as embodied by our Values, Code of Conduct and policies, and we expect our suppliers to work in a way consistent with our approach.

column13: Our current Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP) September 2021 Ã¢ÂÂ September 2024 is our third overall and second Stretch RAP. It seeks to embed and strengthen our reconciliation activities and make them 'business as usual'. The current Stretch RAP outlines our commitments and deliverables to improve and increase our activities to promote reconciliation, including through mutual respect and understanding.
column20: Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP), Climate change strategy

column13: In January 2023, the NSW Government advised that it intended to expand its domestic coal reservation scheme to include producers of export coal. On 16 February 2023, Whitehaven received finalised Directions for Coal Mines as part of the NSW Government's expanded domestic thermal coal reservation policy. From 1 April 2023, Whitehaven's mines were obliged to make specific volumes of suitable thermal coal available for supply to NSW domestic power stations.
column20: NSW Government, coal reservation, Domestic demands

column7: We seek to prevent modern slavery practices in our supply chain and continue to develop and strengthen our approach to assess and manage this risk.

column13: This Code of Conduct (Code) outlines the standard of behaviour expected by all persons working for or on behalf of Whitehaven Coal Limited and its subsidiaries (Whitehaven). The Code promotes a safe, healthy and productive workplace wherever Whitehaven operates. Underpinning the Code is the expectation that all persons performing work for and on behalf of Whitehaven will conduct themselves honestly and professionally. The Code's fundamental principles are: Ã¢ÂÂ¢ act with professionalism, honesty, integrity and fairness; Ã¢ÂÂ¢ treat others with respect and dignity; Ã¢ÂÂ¢ maintain a safe working environment; Ã¢ÂÂ¢ respect and maintain privacy and confidentiality; and Ã¢ÂÂ¢ identify and manage conflicts of interests.

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Our Speak Up Policy encourages anyone to speak up with information about potential misconduct and to report that information. It includes any improper state of affairs or circumstances about the Company. The policy outlines how to report concerns relating to business conduct, the processes we follow to respond to reports and the protections a reporter receives.

column7: The Board has assessed the Company's practice against the Australian Securities Exchange Corporate Governance Council's 'Corporate Governance Principles and Recommendations Ã¢ÂÂ 4th edition' ('ASX Guidelines'). Appendix 4G reflects the Company's compliance with the ASX Guidelines.

We are an active member of numerous industry associations and bodies, including business chambers and councils, that are relevant to the communities in which we operate. Communities Industry associations are essential in advocating public policy positions and matters that affect our sector and helping Australia's minerals sector sustainably benefit our communities and the economy.

column13: In response to feedback from our FY22 workforce engagement survey on the need for more recognition in the workplace, a company-wide reward and recognition program linked to our values was launched. Based on nominations from leaders in the business, our STRIVE Awards program recognises and celebrates the efforts of individuals and teams who made outstanding contributions and delivered excellent outcomes that aligned with our values.
